Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mathematics as a Gatekeeper to Engineering: The interplay between mathematical thinking and design thinking

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research initiation grant seeks to understand how engineering student learning experiences in requisite mathematics courses impact how students learn engineering design. The principle investigator will use a verbal protocol study, which has been used successfully in understanding design thinking in past studies.

The broader significance and importance of this project is in the way it can inform both undergraduate engineering education as well as the national discussion on mathematics at the K-12 level. The researcher has proposed a strong plan to widely disseminate the results of the project that includes outreach to K-12 educators through workshops. Since design is closely tied to innovation, the impact on preparation of the technical workforce in the United States is potentially important. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering undergraduates and practitioners draw on a variety of knowledge bases and skillsets as they engage in engineering work: engineering science; analytical and mathematical knowledge and ways of thinking; and engineering design. In this project, we investigated how undergraduate students engaged in both mathematical ways of thinking and engineering design ways of thinking as they developed a solution to an engineering design task. Many of the first-year engineering participants relied on the design process that they had recently learned in their first-semester class, while the senior engineering, design, and mathematics seniors used a variety of approaches and strategies. Students’ prior design and mathematics experiences impacted some of their approaches to the problem, but we saw a greater impact from prior experiences on how the students self-assessed their mathematical and design abilities. In general, in looking at the processes used by our study participants, we found that mathematical ways of thinking were synergistic with design activities.

 

This project provided opportunities for fifteen undergraduate students to learn research skills – and reflect on their own design processes and practices – as these undergraduates contributed to the analysis of the data. The undergraduates created narrative descriptions of the activities they observed in the video-recordings of the study participants working on the design task. The project also provided opportunities for three graduate students to learn research skills and learn how to mentor undergraduates. Finally, the project led to the creation of a new course on Video Data Analysis and a new course that allows additional undergraduates to engage in Design Process Reflections as they review the descriptions of the design processes used by the study participants, and relate those processes to their own problem solving approaches.
